name: White: 1. e4 Complete Repertoire (Extended)
description: Comprehensive 1.e4 repertoire covering all major Black responses with deep theoretical lines. Features: Italian Game (Giuoco Piano/Pianissimo, Two Knights, Evans Gambit), Alapin Sicilian (both 2...d5 and 2...Nf6), French & Caro-Kann Advance, Scandinavian, Petrov (with Stafford Gambit refutation), Pirc/Modern Austrian Attack, and Alekhine. Written from White's perspective with pedagogical explanations.

tree.explanation: The King's Pawn Opening. We stake a claim in the center, open diagonals for our bishop and queen, and prepare to develop quickly. This is the most popular first move in chess - played by every World Champion.

children.explanation: The Open Game. Black mirrors our central control. This leads to the Italian Game, Spanish, and other classical openings where both sides fight for the center.
Developing with a threat! Our knight attacks e5, forcing Black to defend. This is the most principled move.
The most common defense. Black develops a piece and protects e5. Now we choose our opening system.
The Italian Game! Our bishop targets the weak f7 square (only defended by the king) and prepares to castle. One of the oldest and most natural openings - played since the 16th century.
The Giuoco Piano ('Quiet Game'). Black develops symmetrically, also eyeing f2. This is the most solid response.
Preparing d4 to build a big pawn center. This is the main line, leading to rich strategic play. We'll either play d4 immediately or the slower Pianissimo setup with d3.
Developing and attacking our e4 pawn. Now we must decide: quiet play with d3 (Giuoco Pianissimo) or sharp play with d4.

The Giuoco Pianissimo ('Very Quiet Game'). We solidly protect e4 and plan slow maneuvering: Nbd2-f1-g3 to pressure Black's kingside. Preferred by modern GMs like Anish Giri - safe and strategic with lasting edge.
Solid. Black reinforces e5 and prepares to develop.
Castle early, castle often! Our king is safe and rook is connected. Next: Nbd2, then Nf1-g3.
Both sides have castled. A strategic battle begins.
The knight heads for g3 via f1. This is the signature Giuoco Pianissimo maneuver - our knight will support an eventual f4-f5 break.
Black prepares ...Ba7 to redeploy the bishop and may expand with ...b5.
We tuck the bishop away safely on b3, still eyeing f7. The bishop can later retreat to c2 to support a kingside attack with Re1 and Nf1-g3.
Black repositions. The bishop eyes the a7-g1 diagonal but no longer controls d4.
The knight re-routes to g3. From there it supports f4-f5 and controls key squares. We have a small but lasting edge.
Black develops and offers a trade. We usually decline.
Mission accomplished! The knight reaches its ideal square. We can now play for d4 or launch a kingside attack with h3, Be3, Qd2, and Nh2-f1-g3 if needed.
Black plays flexibly, keeping options open.
We castle and continue with our plan.
The aggressive Center Attack! We immediately challenge Black's center. This leads to sharper, more theoretical play than the Pianissimo.
Black captures. Now we have a critical choice.
We recapture with the pawn, maintaining a strong center but allowing the check.
The annoying check. We must block.
We block with the knight, developing a piece and defending e4. This is the main theoretical line.
Black wins a pawn! But we have compensation - open lines, a strong center, and attacking chances.
We castle and prepare to generate an initiative. Our development lead and open lines compensate for the pawn.
Black takes the knight.
A key move! We sacrifice another pawn to open lines and displace the knight. Our bishops will become powerful.
Black defends. The position is very sharp - we're down material but have strong compensation.
Pinning the knight to the king! Complex play ahead.
Black declines the pawn grab with a central counter.
We capture, opening lines.
An alternative - we block with the bishop and keep our pawn structure intact.
Black trades.
We recapture with the knight, maintaining a solid position.
Sveshnikov's recommendation! We advance the pawn, kicking the knight and gaining space. Very dynamic.
Black counters in the center.
We pin the knight. Sharp play continues.
A slower approach. Black solidifies e5 before developing the knight.
We strike now while Black hasn't developed the kingside knight. This gives us a strong center.
The Evans Gambit! We sacrifice a pawn to deflect Black's bishop and gain rapid development. Very aggressive - a favorite of Morphy and Kasparov!
Black accepts. Declining with 4...Bb6 is safer but gives us free rein in the center.
Gaining tempo on the bishop while preparing d4. This is the whole point of the Evans.
The main line. Black pins our c3 pawn. The bishop looks awkward but prevents cxd4.
We strike in the center as planned! The c3 pawn is pinned but we have huge development.
Black captures. Now 7.cxd4 is impossible due to the pin.
We castle, offering another pawn! After ...dxc3 8.Qb3, we have tremendous pressure on f7. This is the classic Evans Gambit position.
The Mieses Defense - Black doesn't grab more material but develops instead. This is considered one of the best defenses.
We recapture, establishing a strong center.
Black strikes back in the center.
We capture. Complex play ahead with chances for both sides.
Black takes another pawn. Now we attack!
Battery on the a2-g8 diagonal! We threaten Bxf7+ and the b7 pawn. Black is under tremendous pressure.
Black defends f7 but can't castle kingside safely.
We recapture, restoring material equality. Our lead in development and Black's awkward king give us excellent compensation.
Black develops more carefully.
Still our best move - pressure on f7 and b7!
Nigel Short's preference - we attack f7 immediately. Also very dangerous.
Black defends f7.
We castle and continue attacking.
A more careful defense, but allows us to build a strong center.
Pressure on f7! The queen and bishop create threats.
Black defends f7.
We open the position. White has excellent compensation.
The Anderssen Variation - a safer retreat. Played by Anand. The bishop can help defend the king.
We still push for the center!
Black attacks our bishop.
Kasparov's revival move! We keep the bishop and maintain central tension.
We can also recapture the pawn immediately.
Black wins back material. Position is roughly equal but complex.
A common amateur move but gives us a tempo.
We gain tempo hitting the bishop again. Very comfortable for White.
Black declines the gambit. Safer but gives us space.
We gain queenside space and threaten to trap the bishop with a5.
Black prevents a5.
We develop. Our b4 pawn has gained space even if not captured.
The Two Knights Defense! Black counterattacks e4 instead of passively defending with Bc5. More aggressive and leads to exciting play.
The Knight Attack! We immediately threaten Nxf7, forking queen and rook. Played by Fischer, Karpov, and Kasparov. Despite Tarrasch calling it a 'duffer's move', it practically wins a pawn.
The only good defense. Black blocks our bishop and opens the center.
We capture the pawn.
The Polerio Defense - the correct response! Black attacks our bishop instead of recapturing on d5. If 5...Nxd5?? 6.Nxf7! is the deadly Fried Liver Attack.
The Bishop Check line - our best scoring continuation. We check and develop.
Black blocks with the pawn, preparing to recapture on d5.
We capture, giving Black doubled pawns.
Black recaptures. They're down a pawn but have active pieces and attacking chances.
The modern main line! The bishop targets h7 and prevents ...Nd5. After 8...h6, we can play 9.Ne4 trading the strong knight.
Black centralizes the knight.
Gaining space and preparing Ng3. Complex play ahead.
Black kicks our knight. Now 9.Ne4 is strong!
We trade our awkward knight for Black's strong one.
The classical retreat. We're a pawn up with a complex game ahead.
Black kicks the knight.
The main line. The knight retreats and we consolidate our extra pawn.
Black gains space and attacks our knight.
Our knight finds a strong outpost. The position is complex - we're up a pawn but Black has activity.
The Steinitz Variation, revived by Fischer and Short. The knight may go to f4.
An alternative - Black develops the bishop.
We prepare to castle and keep our extra pawn.
The Kieseritzky Variation - we save the bishop with a retreat. Solid but gives Black more play.
Black kicks our knight. Very common.
We retreat. Complex middlegame ahead.
A BLUNDER! This allows the Fried Liver Attack.
The Fried Liver Attack! We sacrifice the knight to expose Black's king. Famous and devastating.
Black must take. The king is now exposed.
Check! We attack the knight and develop the queen with tempo.
Black's king walks into the center. A nightmare!
We develop with threats. White has a winning attack.
The Traxler (Wilkes-Barre) Counter-Gambit! Black ignores the f7 threat and counter-attacks f2. Very sharp and trappy!
The safe approach. We take with check and will get a good game.
Black steps out of check but can't castle.
Strong! We centralize with tempo. White has a clear advantage.
Very complicated after 5...Bxf2+! Only for the brave.
The quiet approach against the Two Knights. We avoid the sharp Ng5 lines and just develop solidly. Good if you want a calmer game.
Now we transpose to Giuoco Pianissimo positions. A solid game for both sides.
We prepare our typical Pianissimo setup.
The Hungarian Defense. Very solid but passive. Black avoids all complications.
We seize the center immediately. Black's passive setup gives us free rein.
Black takes.
We recapture with the knight. Our pieces are very active.
The Paris Defense / Semi-Italian. Solid but slow. Black reinforces e5 before developing.
Strike in the center while Black is slow. We get a nice space advantage.
The Petrov Defense (Russian Game). Black counterattacks instead of defending. Solid and somewhat drawish, but we can get a small edge.
The Classical Variation. We grab the pawn - Black can't take back immediately!
The correct response. Black kicks our knight before taking on e4.
We retreat. The position is equal but we have easy play.
Black recovers the pawn. The game is level.
Grabbing space in the center. Simple chess ahead.
Black supports the knight.
We attack the knight. This leads to typical Petrov positions where White has a small but lasting edge.
Black develops.
We castle. The position is balanced but we have slightly more space.
Black develops.
Challenging Black's center. We maintain a slight pull.
The Stafford Gambit! A trappy gambit popularized online. Black sacrifices a pawn for quick development. Dubious but dangerous if you don't know the refutation!
We must take! Now Black is a pawn down with doubled pawns and no center. But there are many traps...
Black recaptures. They have rapid development but terrible pawn structure.
THE REFUTATION! Simple and devastating. We prepare c3 and d4 to neutralize Black's bishops. Do NOT play 5.e5?? which walks into traps.
Black develops aggressively, eyeing f2.
Perfect! We prepare d4 to limit Black's bishop. After d4, the Stafford Gambit is simply refuted.
Black threatens Nxf2 and Qh4.
We push anyway! After ...Bb6 8.Qe2, we're completely winning - up a pawn with a strong center. Black's 'attack' is an illusion.
Black retreats.
We defend f2 and connect our pieces. White is just winning - a pawn up with a huge center. The Stafford is BUSTED!
A TRAP! This natural-looking move is what Black is hoping for.
Black's knight jumps in and the traps begin!
THE LOSING MOVE! This was actually played in Lowens-Stafford 1950 - the game where this gambit got its name. White resigned immediately.
BOOM! Threatens Bxf2+ and Qh4+. If 7.dxe4 Bxf2+ 8.Ke2 Bg4+ wins the queen! White resigned in the original game.
A common beginner mistake! This loses material after our queen check (the Damiano trap).
Pinning the knight to the king! Black is in trouble.
The best try - Black unpins but blocks their bishop.
We win the knight. After the queen trade, we're a piece up for a pawn.
Even worse! This loses the queen.
DISCOVERED CHECK! The knight attacks Black's queen while the knight on e5 delivers check. We win the queen!
The Philidor Defense. Solid but passive. Black defends e5 instead of counterattacking.
We take the center immediately. Natural and strong.
Black develops.
We develop and pressure e5. White has a comfortable advantage.
Black exchanges.
We recapture. Our knight is powerfully placed.

The Sicilian Defense - Black's most popular and ambitious response to 1.e4. Black fights for the d4 square from the flank. We'll play the Alapin (2.c3) to avoid massive theory while getting a good game.
The Alapin Variation! Instead of entering Black's theoretical maze with 2.Nf3 Nc6/d6 3.d4, we prepare to build an ideal pawn center with d4. Used by Anand, Kasparov, Kramnik, and Carlsen.
The Barmen Defense - the main response. Black strikes back immediately while we can't play Nc3 to attack the queen.
We capture. Taking is best - advancing e5 lets Black equalize easily after ...Bf5.
Black recaptures with the queen. Normally this is bad (early queen development), but here we can't chase it with Nc3.
Mission accomplished! We have our ideal center. Now we develop rapidly.
Natural development, controlling e4.
Solid development. If Black plays ...cxd4, we get an Isolated Queen Pawn (IQP) position - good for attacking players!
Black solidifies and prepares ...Be7 or ...Bd6.
Developing and reinforcing d4. We're slightly better with more space and easy play.
Black exchanges, creating an IQP position.
We recapture. Our isolated d-pawn gives us active pieces and attacking chances.
Black develops.
We develop and challenge the queen.
The queen retreats.
We develop with a typical IQP setup. White has good attacking chances.
Black pins our knight, trying to disrupt our center.
Simple unpinning. We continue with normal development.
Black develops the knight first.
We develop and reinforce d4.
Black develops the knight.
We develop.
Black attacks e4 immediately, hoping to lure it forward.
We accept! We gain space and kick the knight. Black will be cramped.
The knight retreats to the only good square.
Seizing the center as planned.
Black exchanges to relieve the pressure.
The modern approach. We develop before recapturing, keeping Black guessing.
Black prepares ...d6 to challenge our e5 pawn.
Now we recapture. We have a space advantage and easy development.
Black challenges our pawn chain.
We develop the bishop actively.
Black develops.
We castle. A complex middlegame with chances for both sides.
Black develops.
We recapture.
An error! This lets us achieve the ideal center.
We grab the full center!
Black takes.
We recapture with the pawn! Perfect center - exactly what we wanted.
Black prepares ...d5. This can transpose to French-type positions.
We take the center.
Black strikes back.
We transpose to a French Advance! But Black's bishop is outside the pawn chain - a better version for them.
We can also exchange.
Symmetrical pawn structure.
The French Defense. Black will play ...d5 next to challenge our center. A solid, strategic choice. We play the Advance Variation to gain space.
We take the center.
Black challenges our e4 pawn - the defining move of the French.
The Advance Variation! We gain space and lock Black's light-squared bishop behind the pawn chain - a classic French problem.
The standard response - Black attacks our d4 pawn chain immediately.
We reinforce d4. A typical pawn chain battle begins.
Black develops and adds pressure to d4.
The Paulsen Attack - the main line. We develop and defend d4.
The main move - Black attacks d4 and b2. This is the critical position.
Sveshnikov's move - the most popular! We prevent ...Bb4 and prepare to expand. After 6...c4 7.Nbd2 Na5, complex strategic play follows.
Black fixes the pawn structure and gains queenside space.
We develop and prepare to reroute the knight or bishop.
Black controls b3. A complex battle lies ahead.
We prepare to fianchetto. This is a typical setup in modern play.
A modern alternative - the knight heads for f5 to pressure d4.
We grab queenside space.
A solid alternative - we prepare to castle.
Black exchanges.
We recapture.
Black develops the knight to f5 via e7.
We castle. A typical French Advance position.
TRAP ALERT! This looks natural but contains a deadly trap.
Black takes.
We recapture.
BLUNDER! This loses to our trap.
We take the knight!
Black takes our knight.
CHECK! Black loses the queen to the discovered attack. A classic French trap!
The Euwe Variation - Black develops the bishop before committing the queen. A respectable alternative.
We develop and prepare to castle.
The Caro-Kann Defense. Similar to the French but Black's light-squared bishop isn't blocked. We play the Advance Variation for space and an attacking game.
We take the center.
Black challenges our center - the defining move.
The Advance Variation! We gain space. Unlike in the French, Black can develop the bishop to f5 - but we still have good attacking chances.
The main move - Black develops the bishop outside the pawn chain (the advantage over the French!).
The Short Variation, popularized by Nigel Short. Simple and solid - we develop and prepare to castle safely before any fireworks.
Black consolidates. A solid pawn structure.
We develop and prepare to castle. No drama - just solid chess.
Black attacks our d4 pawn.
We reinforce d4 and develop.
Black attacks b2 and d4. A typical idea.
We develop and guard b2 (queen can go to b1).
Black develops.
We castle. A typical Advance Caro-Kann position. Both sides have chances.
Black develops.
We castle. Play continues with each side pursuing their plans.
The Bayonet Attack! Very aggressive - we immediately attack Black's bishop. Sharp but risky.
The bishop retreats. Now we can continue with h4-h5.
We continue the attack on the bishop.
An aggressive alternative - Black strikes at d4 immediately without developing the bishop first.
We reinforce d4. Similar to a French Advance.
The Scandinavian Defense (Center Counter). Black immediately challenges our e4 pawn - but bringing out the queen early is risky!
We take! Black must recapture, usually with the queen.
The main line - Black's queen comes out early. We'll gain time attacking it!
Developing with tempo! The queen must move again.
The Mieses-Kotr Variation - the most popular retreat. The queen eyes e5 and a2.
We take the center. Simple and strong.
Black develops.
We develop and prepare to play Bd2 and castle.
Black develops the bishop actively.
We connect our knights and prepare Bc4 and O-O. White has a comfortable game.
Black solidifies.
We develop actively, eyeing f7. White has a pleasant advantage.
Black plays solidly.
We develop actively.
An alternative retreat - the queen controls c7 and eyes b4.
We take the center. Simple and effective.
Black develops.
We develop.
The most passive retreat. Black wastes time.
We grab the center. White has a clear advantage.
The Modern Scandinavian - Black develops instead of taking back immediately. Riskier but more dynamic.
We take the center and hold our extra pawn.
Black recovers the pawn.
We develop. A normal game continues.
The Pirc Defense. Black will fianchetto the king's bishop and let us build a big center, then attack it later. Hypermodern approach.
We take the full center. Classical play.
Black develops, preparing ...g6 and ...Bg7.
We develop and reinforce our center.
The Pirc setup begins. Black prepares to fianchetto.
The Austrian Attack - the most aggressive response! Fischer's favorite. We prepare to storm the kingside with e4-e5 or even f5.
Black completes the fianchetto.
We develop. A sharp game lies ahead - White has space, Black has counterplay.
Black castles into our attack! Brave.
We develop and prepare to castle or push e5.
Black strikes at our center.
We can take and try to keep the pawn.
The thematic break! We gain space and attack.
Black strikes at the center immediately.
We can take or ignore it with Bb5+.
A quieter approach - we develop solidly.
Black fianchettoes.
We develop and prepare to castle.
The Modern Defense. Similar to the Pirc but even more flexible - Black delays ...Nf6.
We take the full center.
Black fianchettoes.
Simple center occupation. Similar to the Pirc but more flexible.
Black transposes toward Pirc structures.
Austrian Attack! Same aggressive setup as in the Pirc.
Alekhine's Defense. Black invites us to push the pawn and attack the knight. The knight will hop around while we overextend (in theory). Unusual but playable.
We accept the challenge and chase the knight.
The knight retreats to its only good square.
We build a strong center. This is the main line.
Black challenges our center.
Solid development. We maintain our space advantage.
Black pins our knight.
We break the pin and develop. A typical Alekhine position.
Black takes.
We recapture. Our knight is actively placed.
The Four Pawns Attack! Very aggressive - we chase the knight again. Risky but ambitious.
The knight retreats.
All four pawns advance! White has a huge center but it could become a target.
